review.title: How good is the Electricity benchmark for evaluating concept drift adaptation
review.abstract: In this correspondence, we will point out a problem with testing adaptive classifiers on autocorrelated data. In such a case random change alarms may boost the accuracy figures. Hence, we cannot be sure if the adaptation is working well.

metadata.title: How good is the Electricity benchmark for evaluating concept drift adaptation

sections.text: Keywords: data streams, concept drift, evaluation, autocorrelated labels

sections.heading: Testing on the Electricity data
sections.text: In fact, most of us are able to move to another world where we are able to change the world.

sections.heading: Appendix
sections.text: Table 1 reports on classification accuracies tested with MOA implementations (Bifet et al., 2010a). We see that only LeveragingBag and AdaHoeffdingOptionTree exceed the moving average of one. Table 2 collects classification accuracies on the current dataset, as reported in published publications.

referenceMentions.context: Testing on the Electricity data Concept drift (Widmer and Kubat, 1996) has become a popular research topic over the last decade and a lot of adaptive classification algorithms have been developed.
The Electricity dataset due to Harries (1999) is a popular benchmark for testing adaptive classifiers1.
71 (Pfahringer et al., 2007) moving average of one 85.
